DIV1.P: THE Trip to Portsmouth; A COMIC SKETCH OF ONE ACT, WITH SONGS.
LONDON; Printed for T. WALLER, in Fleet-Street; T. BECKET, in the Strand; and G. ROBINSON, in Pater-noster-Row.

DIV1.HEAD: Advertisement.
DIV1.P: THE Editor of these Detached Scenes (the whole of which, except three or four of the Songs, were begun and finished in five Days) humbly presents them to an indulgent Public, in hopes of their excusing the many Errors with which so hasty a Performance must inevitably abound. — Conscious of a Deficiency in point of that critical Merit required in Dramatic Perfor∣mances, his utmost Wish will be accomplished, should the late Naval Review at Portsmouth have enabled him to furnish even the temporary Amuse∣ment of a leisure Hour.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE.
DIV1.STAGE: Bell rings for the music to stop. A short silence ensues; then a man, with a book in his hand, supposed to be the Prompter, runs upon the stage, after Mr. Weston has been called upon two or three times behind the scenes.

SP.L: MR. Weston, Mr. Weston!

STAGE.HI: Mr. Weston answers behind the curtain.

SP.L: I'm coming, I tell you. Don't make such a rout.
Mr. Weston, Mr. Weston!

STAGE.HI: Mr. Weston, pulling the curtain back, meets him.

SP.L: I'm here. Don't you see me? What's all this about?

SP.P: The Prologue is wanted.

SP.L: It is so,—I grant it,
So here, take the Prologue, and now you don't want it.

STAGE.HI: Gives the Man a sheet of paper, and is going.

SP.P: But, Sir,—Who's to speak it?

SP.L: To speak it,—why—who?
Go ask Mr. Foote, friend.

SP.P: He says, Sir, 'tis you.

SP.L: He's mistaken, for once, I will venture to say,
'Tis a serious affair, and quite out of my way:
Sentimental, pathetical, tender, affecting,
Just like his last piece, and his new way of acting.

SP.P: Your speaking, I'm sure, Sir, would give it such grace.—

SP.L: It wou'd;—but who'll give me a tragedy face?—
I tell you, I neither like whining nor ranting,
The groanings and tonings of tragedy canting;
To sigh, and to strut, and to start, and to stare,
My arms throw about, up and down, here and there;
Kick my train in a pet, and with passionate rumble,
Make sun, moon, and stars, a bombastical jumble;
'Till quite out of breath with heroical swagger,
The poison bowl enters, or polish'd tin dagger:
Then quivering I fall, or in simile die,
So, so, or as if, or as when, or as why,
Ti, ti, tum, Ti, ti, tum, Tum, tum, tum, Ti, ti.

SP.P: But, Sir, —

LG.L: I don't like it,—that's all I've to say,
So pray take yourself and the Prologue away.
So now I am Solus, that is, I'm alone,
Suppose I shou'd try at a speech of my own—
An extempore Prologue—The fancy is new—
With your leaves, you shall judge what Tom Weston can do.—
Once on a time, tho' 'twas in Shakespear's days,
Nature and common sense embellish'd play;
Before old English humour turn'd buffoon,
And long e'er Op'ras put wit out of tune.
In that same time, folks did not think by rules,
But as they felt, they spoke—Our fathers were no fools.
Their song was, Mirth admit me of your crew:
But that's all old—'tisn't the thing—'twont do,
The ton is now,—we must have something new.
New sights we've had, new grand Illuminations,
With Jubilees, and Trips, and Installations.—
We have a trip to-night, to shew some shipping;
Suppose the Author is to-night caught tripping?—
These same Play-jobbers, though it is surprizing,
Will always send me on, apologizing.
Thus they come o'er me: Weston, you're a Soul!

L.HI: Do speak my Prologue—you're so dry and droll.

LG.L: I must go on then—I'm serv'd so this night,
As common bail for what bad Poets write.
If—but I hope not—If we're brought to shame,
If you the Author, or the Actors blame,
May we in one request, good Sirs, be friended,
Pray don't give sentence till the piece is ended.

DIV1.HEAD: Dramatis Personae.
DIV1.P: COUNTRYMEN, SAILORS, and SERVANTS, by the rest of the Performers.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE I. A Landscape.

STAGE.HI: [A noise behind—Enter Postillion running across the stage, a fine dress'd Gentleman, but much debilitated, pursuing him, his name Sir Flim∣sey Nervous, who rests upon his stick in the middle of the stage, quite out of breath.]

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: YOU scoundrel, if I could catch you, you dog, I would break every bone in your skin, you rascal; not to look after the lynch-pin, but let the wheel come off, and overturn us within a few yards of a pond. Suppose my Lady should miscarry. What reparation, ha, you dog? what reparation could you make me?

SP.SPEAKER: POSTILLION.
SP.P: Indeed, your honour—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: Don't answer me a single syllable, sirrah, lest I beat you to atoms, you dog.

STAGE.HI: [Shakes his ivory-headed thin bamboo at him.]

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Miss FLIRT.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLIRT.
SP.P: My dear Sir Flimsey, how can you put yourself into such a passion? It was none of the poor fel∣low's fault.

SP.SPEAKER: POSTILLION.
SP.P: No, indeed, your honour—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, fellow;—are not you frighted, my dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLIRT.
SP.P: Me! no, not I indeed. Why the chaise went over as if it had been done for the purpose, and so softly, and took so much time before it tumbled: and then, Sir Flimsey, how you look'd, as if you had been a ghost. I could not help laughing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: But, my dear Betley, you ought to consider.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLIRT.
SP.P: Ought I? but I won't tho'. I never did consider, and I won't begin now. Pray did we come to Ports∣mouth for consideration-sake? Not we, truly. We came out upon a party of pleasure, and pleasure I will have, if I go to sea myself for it. If you must consider, pray consider how the postillion is to get the chaise up again. I see William, our man, stands by the horses.

SP.SPEAKER: POSTILLION.
SP.P: An please your honour—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: No, sir, it does not please my honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLIRT.
SP.P: Lord, don't scold so. Go along, Postillion, and bid my man give half a crown to some of the peo∣ple that are passing along, to help you. You'll soon get it up again, and see if it is not damaged; we'll walk through the field, and get in again at that stile yonder. We are just by Portsmouth, an't we?

SP.SPEAKER: POSTILLION.
SP.P: Yes, madam, please your ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLIRT.
SP.P: Well, well, go along, do as I bid you. What's done can't be undone: take more care for the fu∣ture. [Exit Postillion.] I hate thinking upon what's past. I always love to look forward.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: I wonder, Betsey, how you can encourage such negligent rascals.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLIRT.
SP.P: I wonder how you can say so. But you are as fretful as if you had the tooth-ach. You put one in mind of those travellers who begin a journey out of humour, and are resolved not to be pleas'd with any thing; and when they come back, give the country a bad character, merely to indulge their own ill tempers.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: Zouns, madam! sure I am at liberty to carry what temper I please about with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLIRT.
SP.P:
But I beg you may travel with a good one, sir; or you shan't carry me, I assure you. What, do you think I am bound to bear your megrims, and your
maggots, and your grumblings, your scoldings and swearings, as much as if I was married to you? No, no, I am none of your wife, Sir Flimsey, none of your slave; I am a free English woman, and that for you, that for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: You shou'd remember, madam—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLIRT.
SP.P: I don't chuse it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: Zouns, madam! do you know what I was going to say?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLIRT.
SP.P: Do you know yourself what you was going to say?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: I'll tell you what, madam—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLIRT.
SP.P: And I'll tell you when, Sir Flimsey. When you take a lady out with you, don't domineer so; it won't do. You may bounce about like Torre's' fire∣works, if you will, who's afraid? ha! not me, be∣lieve me: we came out to be merry, and you shan't spoil my sport. If you don't chuse to be good-na∣tur'd, I know who will. Men won't be scarce at this show, I'm certain; there are fine fellows enow to be had here.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: And I suppose as fine women to be had too.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLIRT.
SP.P: Take them, why don't you? go, sir, there's your road; shall I help your honour? So brisk a gentleman as you should have variety, to be sure. I'll go for half a dozen for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: You may go to the devil, if you please, madam; I wish I had never seen you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLIRT.
SP.P: And I wish I had never left my Lord; if I had staid with his lordship I should not have been us'd so.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: Go to him again then.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLIRT.
SP.P: So I will, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: You have my leave, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLIRT.
SP.P: I shan't stay to ask it; so, sir, your's.

STAGE.HI: As she is going he catches her by the sleeve.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY. [Trembling.]
SP.P: Nay, but stay, Betsy.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLIRT.
SP.P: Indeed but I won't tho'. I know his lordship is to be down here, and I won't be tyrannized over by the finest man in the world, no, that I won't. You know how I love you, and that makes you use me thus; if I did not love you, what you say to me would not hurt me so.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: Well, well, I know you do love me dearly; come, don't cry, come, we'll go together. I see the bo has got the chaise up again; come, we'll go in together, there, there, take this, [kisses her and gives her a purse] and lay it out as you please, when you get to Portsmouth.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLIRT.
SP.P: I am su—su—su—sure, if I did'n't love you, better than any woman ever lov'd a man, I would not bear this.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: Well, well, be easy; as soon as we return, I'll give you a new set of dressing plate;—be compos'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLIRT. [Quite calm.]
SP.P: You know the mildness of my temper, Sir Flimsey, and what a fond fool I am, [throws her arms about his neck.] but I don't want the plate, not I. I have cost you money enough already: and I won't have it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY. [Childishly.]
SP.P: But oo sal ave it though.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLIRT. [Coaxing.]
SP.P: No I von't, so I von't.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: But I say oo sal now.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLIRT.
SP.P: No, no, I von't ave the plate: oo sal buy me a little diamond necklace.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: He! he! he! pretty thing: and so I will then. [Exeunt fondling.] He! he! he!

SP.SPEAKER: DOROTHY.
SP.P: Come, Nan, why doesn't thee come along? why, thou art as tiresome as Farmer Thistle's pigs; no making thee stir any how.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter NAN, with her patten in her hand; a country lad with her, holding the other.

SP.SPEAKER: NAN.
SP.P: Nay, Dolly, why dost talk so? I broke the rib∣band of my patten, and I stopp'd to tye it: and got our Joe to hold the other for me.

SP.SPEAKER: DICK.
SP.P: Ay, ay, Joe is better, I believe, at loosening a knot than fastening one.

SP.SPEAKER: JOE.
SP.P: May hap not, Dick. I fancy thee art as good as myself at woman's work, any day.

SP.SPEAKER: DOROTHY.
SP.P: Ye are both bad enough, for that matter, and a'most as false hearted as gentlefolks.

SP.SPEAKER: NAN.
SP.P: As gentlefolks! I defy all the gentlefolks that come to Portsmouth town, be they who they please, Lords, Dukes, Squires, Bushops, or Church War∣dens themselves, to be more mischievous and false than the best of um are, and I speak it to their faces.

SP.SPEAKER: DOROTHY.
SP.P: Lord, what signifies our staying here, chattering? why don't we make haste onward?

SP.SPEAKER: DICK.
SP.P: We have lost Cicely.

SP.SPEAKER: DOROTHY.
SP.P: Well, she's of age, she knows the way to Ports∣mouth, I warrant her; so let's be going, we shall lose the best of the show, if we don't see his Majesty.

SP.SPEAKER: JOE.
SP.P: I sawed him once, when I went up to town with Farmer Petersfield's five four year olds.

SP.SPEAKER: DICK.
SP.P: What manner o' man is he, Joe?

SP.SPEAKER: NAN.
SP.P: Lord, Dick, what is our King George only a man then?

SP.SPEAKER: DICK.
SP.P: A man? why, what would you have him be, foolatum?

SP.SPEAKER: NAN.
SP.P: Nay, I don't know. I am no great scholard, I can neither read, nor write, so how should I tell; O! here's our Cicely come.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter CICELY, faning herself with her hat.

SP.SPEAKER: CICELY.
SP.P: I have walked myself out of breath, to overget you.

SP.SPEAKER: DICK.
SP.P: You did'nt break your patten string, did you, Cicely, and stay'd to tie it?

SP.SPEAKER: CICELY.
SP.P: I don't understand you, not I: but here, see this; I stay'd at Field End, to hear a man sing purely, all about the show that is to be; and so I gave him a halfpenny for the ballad, and I got the tune for nothing; come, you shall hear it.

DIV2.STAGE:
SONG.
I.
The bells are begun, and the music-folks play,
The fine flags are flying in sunshine of day,
The sea and the shore with re-echoings ring,
His Majesty comes, and we honour our King.
II.
The Shepherd, to-day, leaves his flock to their feed,
To-day, the good housewives no marketting heed;
The milk-pail is empty, the spinning-wheel still;
And lasses, to-day, take no corn to the mill.
III.
Our rakes lie neglected along the new hay,
And ploughs are forsook, for the sake of this day;
Abroad all is Mirth, so we seek for a share;
At home, we've left Labour, to look after Care.
IV.
'Tis holyday all, and we'll holyday make,
'Tis all for — God bless him — his Majesty's sake:
Tho' simple my song is, and simply I sing,
Yet who can say better than, Long live the King.
Exeunt, singing.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE II.
DIV2.STAGE: [One of the streets in Portsmouth; a tavern window open; some Bucks appear there drunk; French horns playing above. Two Girls cross the stage, and one of the Bucks calls out to them to stop.]

SP.SPEAKER: BUCK.
SP.P: Molly, come up; come up, Lucy.

STAGE.HI: The two girls turn to see who call'd, and tossing their heads scornfully, as in contempt, go out.

SP.P: O, ho! what they won't come up, why then I'll come down.

STAGE.HI: He strides over the balcony, and coming down tumbles upon the stage. Waiter comes out to him.

SP.SPEAKER: WAITER.
SP.P: I hope your honour han't hurt yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: BUCK.
SP.P: Hurt myself! what's that to you, Sir? are you a surgeon, Mr. Question-asker? No, Sir, I havn't hurt myself. I got a knock upon my head, but there's nothing in that.

SP.SPEAKER: WAITER.
SP.P: I hope no offence, your honour.

SP.SPEAKER: BUCK.
SP.P: Damn your fences: I don't want any of your fencing, not I. Where's the girls? go fetch them. There they are. So ho! so ho! go turn them. [Exit Waiter.] I should like to see a good course between a girl and a waiter: I'll hold six to four upon the wench, though, that she doubles upon him.—How now! who's this?

STAGE.HI: Enter a young fellow, ridiculously dressed, in the present mode, with a servant carrying a bundle, and a Postil∣lion another; the servant carries both the bundles into the opposite house, and the young fellow pays the Postil∣lion, who goes out; mean while the Buck, who has been looking at him, says,

SP.SPEAKER: BUCK.
SP.P: This must be some French Hair-Dresser, or Rope-Dancer, or some such a sort of an outlandish Merry Andrew; no, 'tis Jack Inkle, by all that's comical: give me your hand, if you are he, and we'll have one bottle together.

SP.SPEAKER: INKLE.
SP.P: I beg, my dear Bumper, you'll excuse me: I cannot touch a drop of strong liquor: I am quite reform'd.

SP.SPEAKER: BUCK.
SP.P: Ay, and transform'd too. For you look like— [walks round him] I don't know what you look like, except it is a sugar figure, made all of painted sweetmeats, upon the top of a twelfth-cake. Are you, Jack Inkle, or are you not? that's the ques∣tion,—To be, or not to be?

SP.SPEAKER: INKLE.
SP.P: My dear friend, and school-fellow, you'll permit me to pass, and for heaven's sake don't expose me.

SP.SPEAKER: BUCK.
SP.P: No, you do that yourself. Did I ever think to see Jack Inkle, the Haberdasher's son in Thread∣needle-street, turn'd into a tiddidol!

SP.SPEAKER: INKLE.
SP.P: Dear Tom, I request you won't say here, I'm a Ha∣berdasher's son. I'm certain you can keep a secret.

SP.SPEAKER: BUCK.
SP.P: Yes, if I don't think it worth telling.

SP.SPEAKER: INKLE.
SP.P: You must know then, that last week at Ranelagh, I got acquainted with a Woman of Quality; and she appointed to meet me here.

SP.SPEAKER: BUCK.
SP.P: She lost her lap-dog, I suppose, and had a mind to make you his proxy; or hire you for a page to carry her knotting-bag. You are no more fit for a fine woman, than a butterfly is to build a bird's-nest: Why you belong to some Milliner's manu∣factory. [Inkle offers to go away, Buck lays hold of him.] Nay, nay, you shan't steal off neither,— if your father was to see you in this dress!—Damn it, that ever any school-fellow of mine should play truant from old port, and good roast beef, to live upon whey, and wafer-paper!—I only wish your father was to see you; that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: INKLE.
SP.P: Ay: but he's safe enough, and far enough. I don't fear him. My father would no more come to such a hurrying, expensive place as this is, than I would jump into the sea with my clothes on: no, no; he hates all shew.

SP.SPEAKER: BUCK.
SP.P: Such a shew as you make, Jack, I think every body would hate.—But come, we must have one bottle.

SP.SPEAKER: INKLE.
SP.P: Any other time I will, but now—

SP.SPEAKER: BUCK.
SP.P: Why now is the time. As for to-morrow, that's a damn'd slippery time, and bilks every body.— There's some devilish jolly fellows above;—we have been keeping it up all night, drinking his Majesty's health, and so shall you: we'll make you free of Portsmouth.

SP.SPEAKER: INKLE.
SP.P: I beg you'll not force me now, nor call me Inkle. I have taken a lodging in that house; and there I am to pass for a young nobleman, my Lord Trueby.

SP.SPEAKER: BUCK.
SP.P: My Lord Booby, you mean.—Do you look like a Lord?—Let me examine you again. — Yes, yes, you may pass well enough for such a thing amongst people who know no better.—But come, we will have a bottle to wet your title; one half pint bumper to christen your Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: INKLE.
SP.P: I'll pay for ten bottles.—

SP.SPEAKER: BUCK.
SP.P: Damn your pay, Sir—My Lord, I mean—I beg your titleship's pardon; but if your dishonourable∣ness is so shy, and won't drink with an old school∣fellow, I'll call my boat's crew, and have you toss'd in a tarpaulin.

SP.SPEAKER: INKLE.
SP.P: O for heaven's sake! you'll frighten me into fits.

DIV2.STAGE: [Inkle attempts to run away, and the Buck seizes him by the tail of his wig. Inkle, with his back to the Buck, his face or profile to the audience, attempts to dis∣engage himself, expressing great pain in his gestures.

SP.SPEAKER: BUCK.
SP.P: Avast, Mr. Ladybird, you're not flown yet. [Sings.] A very pretty fancy, a rare gallantée shew. This is one of the Monkeyronies, and I have got hold of Pug's tail. [Inkle escapes, leaving the tail in the Buck's hands.] This is devilish droll, faith; this is a new way of giving bail. — Now can I be indicted for a robbery, or is this fair plunder? This looks like a back-stay to keep the head steady. A-head!—Damn it, what sort of heads must those be, who have such tails to them? why they look like overgrown weeds, with their roots uppermost.

SP.SPEAKER: WAITER.
SP.P: I could not overtake the ladies, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: BUCK.
SP.P: Then take me over the way, to my lodgings there; [gives him the tail] this will serve you to pull the bell in your tap-room; and you'll put it to a better use than the owner did.—I'll try to sleep a little—my senses seem to be in an uproar— [staggers] I have not a good understanding of things at present. I'm almost drunk Will, an't I?

SP.SPEAKER: WAITER.
SP.P: No, your honour; only as one may say, I ax pardon, but that your Honour's reason is a little hurried.

SP.SPEAKER: BUCK.
SP.P: Yes, I distanced it; I run of the wrong side the post with it, and left it upon the Common last night; and, if any body should happen to find it, and they can't make a better use of it than I have, I would not advise them to give themselves the trouble of picking it up.

STAGE.HI: Enter, a Scotch Lady Lochiel, the Landlord following; two Watermen with baggage attending.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady LOCHIEL.
SP.P: Hoot awaw, mon, tis a deal o' muckle siller to gie for a temporary sleeping-place; gin ye'll gang the length o' Musselborough, ain wad ha as gued a hoose as any Laird o' th' ilk for a hauntle less siller—ye ask muckle mair for ane o' your wie bits of roomies than ane wud ha for a hale hoose fit for Lord Provost at Edingburgh, either in the new Toon, or the best place in auld reekie. There are e'en the brithers, the architects, whare gutterbloods of that bonny town, I dare say, wud na ask mare for ane o' their bra houses in th' Adelphi—when I left hame, I laid down sic rule o' oeconomy, that I am sure canno be adher'd to in sic a dear place. [aside.] — Indeed, honest man, your demands are far o'er exorbitant, an wi aw bears sic a look of extortion, that ane would be at a stammer to ken whether I had na mista'en the town of Portsmouth, an gat my sel at ane o' the foreign simmer places, among some o' the English nobility, wha ga ilk aw foreign the preferance, and like aw fashions abroad, better than their ain at hame, estimating the parfections o' sic a commodity, according to its extravagant charge.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: I can shew your Ladyship other apartments that are cheaper. I have some up three pair of stairs; but I did not presume to shew them as fit for your Ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P:
The height o' the rooms wad be na objection wi' me—three story is na height at all—my town hoose at bonny Edingburgh is up the aught story, in Goudeluck's Land; an had na it been for Mr.
M'Naughton, the Cloth-Merchant, wha flitted fra the eleventh story, up the scale stairs, to the saxth aboon me, I wad a taen the house on the fourteenth story, for the prospect; where ane may see doon a the stree, fra the Lucken Booths to the Nether Bow.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: I have some very good front garrets, that have a prospect of the Harbour — Would your Ladyship chuse them?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: By my troth, cheeld, you're na very blate. Had na ye sic an unco stock of assurance, I dinna ken how ye could mouthban sic a very affronting pro∣posal: Wha do ye tak me for, that ye presume to tak sic a Liberty? Do ye think I wad so far forget my sel as e'en to set a fit in the best garrat i' th' town; an sa far tak fra my dignity, as gang to sleep in any ane o' them? hoo dare ye tak upoon you, Sir, to ask me to gang there? Was na ye a muckle donnart, and had ye but a spunk a gued breeding in your book, ye wad na mak sic a muckle breach o' gued manners. God's mercy, does the cheeld ken wha he's specken to?

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: Indeed, my Lady, I ask your Ladyship ten thou∣sand pardons. I would not be guilty of the least offence towards your Ladyship. But indeed, my Lady, we are at very extraordinary expences now; and as your Ladyship sent me word you would be here, I have kept the rooms for you. I might have had more money for them, if I would have parted with them.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P:
It would na ha been the art nor part of an ho∣nest cheeld to ha done sa, sir. Ye mun ha the siller,
sir; I canna help it. The Laird of Lochiel, ye ken him coming there, sir, [points] he's my ain brither; he wud ha na peace at my bidding, but was a'most daft untull I gid him his ain way, and gang'd my sel wi him, to speer after this bonny sight at your town.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: I am very sorry, your Ladyship was obliged to cross the water from Gosport. I hope you met with no accident by the way.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Ye sal ken sir, that the t'ither night we came to a little towny; how caw ye it? Godalmin; and our fause cheeld of a Coachman, was sic a dolt, to turn us ilka ane o'er upon a muckle midding; and an auld wife, wha's bouk was as big as a peat mow, wambled herself along me, wi' sic a thump, that I wud na gang intull the coach again, but staid in the towny I was telling about, and this morning they had me up before the laverocks 'gan to sing, and we gang'd to the place anent this, and then the gued men in the boat, hurld us o'er here, in the busking of a cockernonny.

STAGE.HI: Enter the Laird, and a Frenchman.

DIV2.P: O! here's the Laird. How's aw wi' ye, Lauchlin?

SP.SPEAKER: LAIRD.
SP.P: Unco weel. How's aw wi' your sel my Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: Brawley, I thank ye for speering, Man, and Monsieur, I hope ye are weel?

SP.SPEAKER: MONSIEUR.
SP.P: A votre service, votre service, Mademoiselle, tou∣jour Gay, I hope de boat did no mak your Lady∣ship sick: it was all one side, all one side, comme sa.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: This is an uncoo bra place, and the ships here, are for aw the world like the shipping in the harbour of Leith, which is a wie bit aneath the town of Edinburgh.

SP.SPEAKER: MONSIEUR.
SP.P: Eh, mon dieu, Madam, in my country, my Lady, if you was to see de ships, and de boats, 'tis here all bagatelle, noting at all; the Roy de France, Madam, de grand Monarch, has ten hundred times more a ships den de English.

SP.SPEAKER: LAIRD.
SP.P: Troth, Sir, ye sa right, ye had so mony ships in the late war, that ye cou'd na weel tull what to do wi' em, and the English were oblig'd to tak them off your hands.

SP.SPEAKER: MONSIEUR.
SP.P: O dat was all fortune de la guerre, all accident.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: If your Ladyship pleases, I'll wait upon you to my wife, my Lady, to choose your apartments. I ask pardon for my mistake.

SP.SPEAKER: LADY.
SP.P: I think my Landlord a very polite person in gued troth, so come awa, Lauchlin.

SP.SPEAKER: MONSIEUR.
SP.P: En verite, Monsieur Ecossois, de English very little while ago was all barbare, all savage, we did teach dem de politesse, did show dem de bon mien, de bon grace, de bon ton.

SP.SPEAKER: LAIRD.
SP.P:
Ye mun excuse me there, Sir, it was my ain coun∣trymen,
that gae the idlom to the South Britons, to ken, a tincture of erudition and elegance.

SP.SPEAKER: MONSIEUR.
SP.P: Excusez moi. I have know de better; we did teach dem de bow, and de dance, and de frizeurs, and we did put deir heads in order.

SP.SPEAKER: LAIRD.
SP.P: The outsides of their heeds, I ken ye might, sir; but I dinna believe you care much to meddle wi' the insides of them.

SP.SPEAKER: MONSIEUR.
SP.P: De English dey tink too much, de French do not tink at all. Our Grand Monarch will not let us tink; he say, what business ave mon subjects to tink? I will tink for dem all, sowe let him; now sir, here's tout a contrarie—de people here, will tink all, dey will tink for de King, and will not let de King tink for himself at all.

SP.SPEAKER: LAIRD.
SP.P: Troth, sir, I dinna ken ought aboot the matter, for muckle may be said on both sides, and I will always keep myself clear of malevolence: But ye shall hear a sang, sir, of my ain fabricating, sung by a lassie, who wi tunefu voice can bonnily lilt it o'er the lee. Come awa, come awa, Katty.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter KATTY.

SP.SPEAKER: KATTY.
SP.P: What's your wull, brither?—

SP.SPEAKER: LAIRD.
SP.P: Ye remember the sang about the discreet lad?

SP.SPEAKER: KATTY.
SP.P: Troth do I, sir.—

SP.SPEAKER: LAIRD.
SP.P: Vary weel, vary weel then; let's ha' it.—
SP.STAGE:
SONG.
I.
The lad discreet, with healthfu heart
Taks brawly ilka honest part;
He laughs to scorn daft Scandal's wrang,
And chearfu sings Contentment's sang.
II.
The cadgy lad lilts doon the field,
O'er heather braes, by whuns, or bield,
Fra ilka ill he turns ajee;
Sic, sic a life's the life for me.
III.
To king, my country, faith, and hame,
Sic love I bear, I'll bear na shame;
The din of fasheous cheils fra me;
Na, na, sic life, na, na, for me.
IV.
A pawky loon lo'es paltry pelf,
Wa worth the dowie cankart elf;
If siller comes, e'en lat it be,
But honour first of aw for me.
SP.P: But sir, let us awa wi' this parle, and gang ben the huse, and bite a bit, and tak a sup, for the sea has sharpened my appetite as much as if I had come oer the pass of Gillicranky.

SP.SPEAKER: MONSIEUR.
SP.P: De tout mon coeur, my Lor, but prenez prenez garde jai ditez vouz; take care of de imposition, de English be de devil for taking de money out of de foreigner's pockets.

SP.SPEAKER: LAIRD.
SP.P:
Troth, Sir, but the English first put it in there; but nee'r heed, sir, the Laird of Lochiel has na come so far north for naithing. I can speer what's to be ken'd here. I can grip my siller unco weel,
sir, I love to live as winsome as ony mon i' the south, sir, but I will tak heed hoos aw wi' my cash, and tak counsel of my ain Oeconomy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. SIMPSON.
SP.P: Mr. Hearty, I'm your very humble servant. I little expected a Gentleman of so philosophic a turn, as you are, would think it worth while to leave solitude and reflection for parade and bustle.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTY.
SP.P: Why, really, Mr. Simpson, there are very few sights that would draw me a field's length to look at them; but such an appearance as this promises to be, is an exception. This will be an exhibition that no part of the world can equal; a King of Great Britain reviewing his Royal Navy; and en∣couraging, by his presence, his honest-hearted sailors, is such a picture, that any Englishman must exult in. It has long been wished for, and the accomplishment of it must give universal satisfac∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: SIMPSON.
SP.P: Long may he live to make all his subjects so happy, say I.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTY.
SP.P: And I say amen to it. [Shouting behind, and the Boatswain's call sounded.] There they are; the hap∣py heroes of the present moment. There is some∣thing so truly original in the character of English seamen, so hearty, and so disinterested, which is not to be met with in any other kingdom.

SP.SPEAKER: SIMPSON.
SP.P: No, nor among any other people even here.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTY.
SP.P: Is it not a pity they should be so brave, and yet so thoughtless?

SP.SPEAKER: SIMPSON.
SP.P: Did you ever know a philosopher have fine spirits? their active undauntedness carries them beyond the call of reflection; and I really think them so much the happier for it.

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTY.
SP.P: The happier for it?—

SP.SPEAKER: SIMPSON.
SP.P: Ay, the happier, Sir; but I am for no moral observations; this is a day of joy and jollity, and I am determined to suit myself to all conditions, and join company with the group of sailors that are coming towards us. I like them, and will make one in their party, drink with them, sing with them—

SP.SPEAKER: HEARTY.
SP.P: What, in the street too?

SP.SPEAKER: SIMPSON.
SP.P: What's that to me! I came out to be pleas'd; I give ceremony to the winds. This is a day of Jubilee, every man casts off restraint; at least they should do so, and I'll set them an example.

SP.SPEAKER: First SAILOR.
SP.P: Avast, lads, let us drop anchor here a little;—here, tapster, hand our a can of grog.

SP.SPEAKER: Second SAILOR.
SP.P: Come, bear a hand though, 'cause our Commo∣dore King George is coming.

DIV2.STAGE:
SONG.
I.
Come, bustle, bustle, drink about,
And let us merry be;
Our can is full, we'll pump it out,
And then all hands to sea.
II.
Fine Miss, at dancing-school is taught
The Minuet to tread;
But we go better, when we've brought
The fore-tack to cat-head.
III.
The Jockey's call'd, to horse, to horse,
And swiftly rides the race;
But swifter far we shape our course,
When we are giving chace.
IV.
When horns and shouts the forest rend,
His pack the huntsman cheers;
As loud we hollow, when we send
A broadside to Mounsieurs.
V.
The what's-their-names at uproars squall,
With music fine and soft;
But better sounds our Boatswain's call,
All hands, all hands aloft.
VI.
What's got at sea, we spend on shore,
With sweethearts, or our wives;—
And then, my boys, hoist sail for more;
Thus passes Sailors lives.
Enter SIMPSON.

SP.SPEAKER: SIMPSON.
SP.P: How fares it my merry fellows?

SP.SPEAKER: Second SAILOR.
SP.P: Thank you, thank you, sir. Make way there, brace your sails a-back, step aft a little, and let the Gentleman come into a birth, if he pleases to drink with us.

SP.SPEAKER: First SAILOR.
SP.P: Belay that, Jack, why you know no more of manners, than as thof you had never been at sea. Why don't you ax the Gemman to drink with us, without heaving the tankard alongside of him, as if you had a mind he should run foul of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Second SAILOR.
SP.P: No offence, I hope, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: SIMPSON.
SP.P: O no, not in the least—Come, my lads, here's his Majesty's health—

STAGE.HI: Sailors give three cheers, and the Boatswain pipes.

SP.SPEAKER: First SAILOR.
SP.P: Here's success to the Barfleur, and King George's health. He is coming amongst us, and God bless him, and that's all the harm I wish him.

SP.SPEAKER: SIMPSON.
SP.P: Come, my jolly hearts, suppose we have another song; I'll try at one myself if you'll bear a chorus.

SP.SPEAKER: ALL.
SP.P: Ay, ay, ay.

DIV2.STAGE:
SONG.
I.
Ye free-born sons, Britannia's boast,
Firm as your rock-surrounded coast,
Ye Sovereigns of the Sea!
On every shor where salt tides roll,
From east to west, from pole to pole,
Fair Conquest celebrates your name,
Witness'd aloud by wondering fame,
Ye lads who dare be free!
II.
Mistake me not, my hearts of oak,
I scorn with Liberty to joke;
Ye Sovereigns of the Sea!
Assist, uphold your church and state,
Your great men good, and good men great,
Awe all abroad, at home unite,
And jolly join in Faction's spite,
Then, then, my friends, you're free.
III.
Ye sovereign of wide Ocean's waves,
To heros' long enshrin'd in graves,
A requiem let us sing:
I Alfred, Henry, Edward name;
Then, William, our deliverer came;
May future ages Brunswick own,
Perpetual heir to Britain's throne;
So here's God save the King.
Exeunt, singing God save our noble King.

STAGE.HI: [Here a dance, with marrow-bones and cleavers.]

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE—A Parlour.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY. [Rising up in a passion.]
SP.P: Why then the house may go to the Devil, for what I care.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD
SP.P: This is a very pretty time to put yourself in a passion, and the whole house into confusion; and now, in about an hour's time, when the people come back, who are gone to meet his Majesty, and the town fills, we shall have nothing ready.

SP.SPEAKER: LANLADY.
SP.P: Yes, but we shall have every thing ready. But would it not vex any body to hear you talk of not raising the prices of your things? Shall we ever have such another opportunity? Such a sight as this may never happen here again: and we should make hay while the sun shines. Don't we pay the King many taxes, and why may we not tax the people, who come to see his Majesty? And so then we may say, in a manner, as how, the King makes his subjects pay us again.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: I cannot charge my customers so. My conscience will not let me.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: Your conscience? what has a publican to do with conscience? mind your business; and put con∣science behind the bar-board: I say conscience, truly. I wonder how many fine equipages we should wait upon, if their keepers had always stood upon con∣science.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: Why, my dear, we must live after this show is over.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: To be sure, and so we must, and this is the way to do it. People that come down here expect to pay dear for every thing they have; and besides, most of um are Londoners, and you know they never mind what they do with their money, if they can see any thing strange for it.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: I have not the heart to be guilty of any imposition.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: No, I know you have no heart: ay, Tom, Tom, if I hadn't a better heart than you have, we should never get a fortune for our daughter. How do you think fortunes are got now-a-days.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter GROANLY, a Methodist.
DIV2.P: O dear, Mr. Groanly, I'm glad to see you, I wish you would convince my husband that we ought to be as sharp as our neighbours; pray now, doctor, is there is any sin in short measure?

SP.SPEAKER: GROANLY.
SP.P: Why, as spirituous liquors are unwholesome li∣quors, the less you sell your customers, the less harm they can receive; for you hinder them from drink∣ing too much, by taking care to give them too little.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: Well, Doctor, I shall be glad to hear you some other time;—see, speak in the Lyon there. [Bell rings.] This is going to be a very busy time—Hark! there's a carriage drove into the yard—go, go, wait upon it, wife; and do you, Doctor, go and wait where you please.

SP.SPEAKER: WAITER.
SP.P: Maister, the barge's crew of the Barfleur desire to have some place to sit in for half an hour, before the hurry begins, and I think they may have this room a little.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: That's true, and so they shall. We must not slight them, they'll stick by us, when this show is all over and gone.

SP.SPEAKER: WAITER.
SP.P: Ay, maister, a tar jacket very often, is a better customer than a lac'd waistcoat. [Bells ring on dif∣ferent sides.] Coming, coming, coming.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE,—Another Room in the same Inn.
DIV2.STAGE: Landlord returns, shewing Sir Flimsey in, Landlady attending Miss Flirt, Waiters behind.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: If your honour will be pleased to walk in here, for the present, while your honour's apartment is getting ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: Ay, ay, with all my heart; yes, yes, a busy time this is like to be, landlord.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: Yes, sir, we hope so.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: And if her Ladyship pleases, I'll wait on her La∣dyship, to show her Ladyship her Ladyship's bed∣chamber, and her Ladyship's dressing-room. I am sure I have taken as much care of it for your Lady∣ship, as if your Ladyship was the Queen's Majesty herself.

DIV2.STAGE: Exeunt Landlady and Miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: Come, landlord, sit down; that's the finest girl in the world, Tom, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: Her honour seems to be very handsome.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I believe she is indeed: Well, land∣lord, and how goes the world with you?

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: Why, sir, for want of a war, Portsmouth is very dull, very dull indeed, sir; our people pray for a war most heartily.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: They do!—they pray for the undoing of others to set themselves up,—very charitable, truly.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: It's very natural, your honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: Well, well, bring us a bottle of Champaign. [Exit Landlord.] In this peaceable time, people pray here for a war; and I don't doubt but in a very healthy time, physicians pray for a plague. It is something rather on the wrong side of humanity to help ourselves by hurting our neighbours; how∣ever, as my landlord says, it is very natural tho'— and yet we pretend to be a civilized people.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Landlord with wine.
DIV2.P: Well, landlord, how long will it be before his Majesty comes?

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: We expect the King in about an hour's time, sir; all the people of our town are gone beyond the Fortifications to meet him; and that makes Ports∣mouth so quiet at present. Sir, your Honour's health: I think I never saw your Honour look better.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P:
Why, landlord, I'm grown young again. I have been dipped in Medea's kettle. A fine girl is the grand elixir of life, the chief restorative, and na∣ture's supernaculum; and I have got the sweetest wench in the world; so mild, so affable, none of
the haughty airs of matrimony. I have all the sweets of wedlock without any of the bitters. All roses without thorns.—A wife! damn it, mine was insupportable. I was forced to part with her. So domineering, such a vixen, and so costly, she would have ruined me. Now this girl checks me when I would give her any thing. She refused a service of plate that I offered her to-day. She said it was too expensive. Now I never indeed proffer'd to give my wife such a thing; but if I had, she would have took it, yes, yes, yes, she wou'd have taken it.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: Pray, Sir: No offence, I hope; Is Lady Ner∣vous in town.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: I don't know. I never enquire after her. She made me toss her in two hundred pounds per ann. more when we parted: She bullied me into it— She was a perfect tyrant. Now this girl is as mild as a lamb, tender as a turtle, and no more haughti∣ness in her than in a milk-maid. I never did a better thing than parting from Lady Nervous. And, I am certain that married men of fashion will never live happy, until they have sense and spirit enough to make their wives live upon the board wages of a separate maintenance.

SP.SPEAKER: WAITER.
SP.P: Mr. Inkle presents his respects to you, Sir Flim∣sey, and says as how, seeing your Honour come out of the post-chaise, he should be glad to have the honour of taking a glass with your Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P:
Oh, my compliments to him; by all means; I shall be glad to see him. [Exit Waiter.] Let me
see, how many years have Inkle and I been ac∣quainted? it was in the mayoralty of Sir Humfrey, —no—yes—of Sir Leather—

DIV2.STAGE: [Enter OLD INKLE.]
DIV2.P: My old acquaintance, Master Inkle, I am glad to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Old INKLE.
SP.P: And I shall be always glad to see you, Sir Flim-sey,—But, Lord, what a place this is! Mercy upon us! the people are all mad: why the roads are lined with men, women, and children; the hills, and the hedges, and the trees, and the tops of the houses, and the chimney tops, and upon the walls, and out of the windows, all staring and gaping, like peeping Tom of Coventry. No work done this week, I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: Do you think every body will be idle here?

SP.SPEAKER: Old INKLE.
SP.P: You gentlemen of fortune, indeed, may think pleasure an employment, but we people in trade must look after labour; and we may look, and look again, its all over with us: what with inclo∣sures, and lotteries, and masquerades; though, to be sure, masquerades did help trade a little, and then they wanted to put them down, as if they had not a mind to permit any thing that was for the good of this country.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: I reckon, Mr. Inkle, your warehouse did pretty well with dresses and domino's.

SP.SPEAKER: Old INKLE.
SP.P:
Pretty well, pretty well, Sir. I might have done better if we could have got an act of parlia∣ment for Masquerades. But no, I will say that for them, nothing for the good of Old England. I don't know what will become of us for my part,—
hurrying here, driving there, post chaises rattling to the sea-water as if all the world wanted dipping, —then, all in a hurry to Portsmouth, next to Ox∣ford, and next to—I wonder where they'll go next. Lord, have mercy upon us! I warrant now my son would as soon turn papist, as ramble to any of these raree-shows. No, no, he's busy at home, I'm sure, posting his books, copying letters, or taking an account of stock. He hates going to these sights as much as I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: How came you here now?

SP.SPEAKER: Old INKLE.
SP.P: Why, sir, a fellow, five hundred pounds in my debt, was running away, sir. I heard of him, and took him here, just as he was going on board of a ship for the East-Indies; and now I am going home again.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: Won't you stay and see the grand review, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Old INKLE.
SP.P: Can I get any money by it? Do you think his Majesty will give me an order if I stay?—No, no, I know better, I won't throw away my money.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: But this is all for the encouragement of trade.

SP.SPEAKER: Old INKLE.
SP.P: Not of mine, tho' it does your's, sir. I'm not for any thing but what I can get something by; then I am as ready and willing to join in it as another.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: A very wary man you are, Mr. Inkle.

SP.SPEAKER: Old INKLE.
SP.P: Ay, sir, I always mind the main chance. I never commit indiscretions myself, nor ever excuse them in another. Prudence is the guide of all my actions. I never was in a passion in my life, not I; none of your comical fellows could ever make me laugh. Now, my son, is exactly like me.

STAGE.HI: Anoise behind, and the Buck speaks within the scenes.

SP.SPEAKER: BUCK
SP.P: But then I tell you, you shall. I have chopped upon you once more, and a bottle of Madeira we will have.

STAGE.HI: Pulls in young Inkle. The father and son stare at each other.

SP.SPEAKER: Old INKLE.
SP.P: Why, I am astonished! I am petrified! are you my son Inkle?

SP.SPEAKER: BUCK.
SP.P: Yes, I'll swear it. This is Jack Inkle, that was; and my Lord Trueby, that is; and we'll wet his title.

SP.SPEAKER: Old INKLE.
SP.P: Why, you dog!—Why, you villain!—

SP.SPEAKER: Y. INKLE.
SP.P: Dear father, I hope you'll forgive me.

SP.SPEAKER: Old INKLE.
SP.P: Why you know, Devil's whelp, that I never did nor ever will forgive. I'll horsewhip you all the way home again: where did you get money for these fine cloaths, sir? why, you dog, you have robbed me; I'll have you hang'd, sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: BUCK.
SP.P: Be a little sober, sir.—

SP.SPEAKER: O. INKLE.
SP.P: Strip, hangdog, strip; my money bought these cloaths, and I will have them. [Y. Inkle pulls off his coat, waistcoat, sword, and wig, and his father seizes them] And now, you rascal, never see my face again; never, hangdog.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: I thought, Mr. Inkle, you never put yourself in a passion.

SP.SPEAKER: O. INKLE.
SP.P: I am not in a passion—I am only—No, sir, I scorn to be in a passion—but that undutiful extrava∣gant villain—

SP.SPEAKER: BUCK.
SP.P: Only be prudent a little.

SP.SPEAKER: O. INKLE.
SP.P: Stand away, puppy.

STAGE.HI: Exit with the cloaths, and shoves the Buck down.

SP.SPEAKER: BUCK.
SP.P: So, I am served right, by concerning myself with other peoples business.—Your father's a fierce man, Jack; he has stripp'd you, and has, I think, given me a set down too. Help me up—Come, courage lad. [sings] Let not thy noble courage be cast down. I'll take care of you, I'll clap you on a jacket and trowsers. You can never be rated able indeed, but you'll pass in ordinary well enough. We'll give you a birth in the cockpit, as the surgeon's plaister spreader; or, as you are quite delicate, suppose we enter you principal page to the admiral's tea-kettle. —Why, you are like a little fighting cock, cut out of feathers; so, come along bantam, come along.

STAGE.NOTE: N. B. This scene of Inkle's was thought too long, and there∣fore omitted after the first night's representation.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: Upon my honour, I think the fop has been finely served; it is monstrously impertinent for these me∣chanics to ape us men of fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: Indeed, your honour, things are come to such a pass as to dress, that it was but last week I had two people in fine laced cloaths, with swords by their sides, came to my house, and called for Burgundy and Champaigne, and talk'd as familiarly about the court as I should about my cellar; and spoke of no∣blemen by their Christian names of Jack, Will, and Tom, that I took them for dukes or lords at least, and yet one was but a hair-dresser, and the other a tooth-drawer.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Mr. SNEER.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: Mr. Sneer, your very humble servant; I sent for you to drink a glass with me. I want to hear you talk upon the present times. I know you are a bold man; you dare say anything. Here's a bumper to you. The liberties of the subject for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: With all my heart, Sir Flimsey; the liberty of the subject.—But I never expect to see that again. —However, I wish well to it—Ah! ah! ah! li∣berty! yes, yes, ay! ay! ay! [Expresses several very uneasy gesticulations.] Do you know, Sir Flimsey, what is to become of us.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: Become of us; why we are come to see what's to be seen, and then—Why, will not this Naval re∣view be a most magnificient sight?

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: I wish no harm may come from it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: Harm!

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: Ay, harm; I can see farther into this than some people imagine. I think I can, that's all. I think I can see this scheme plain,—plain.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: Scheme!

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: Ay, sir; all this sort of show that is to be, is a scheme of the Ministry to distress the people.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: I rather think it is to divert the people.

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: A very pretty time to take diversions, truly!—a very pretty time, indeed. Here we don't know how soon we may want our gunpowder, and we are throwing it away in fireworks at Ranelagh, in fireworks at Marybone, and fireworks at Ports∣mouth; but let them go on, that's all, that's all; let them go on!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: You look at things through the wrong end of the perspective.

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P:
I do, do I? very likely, to be sure. I only wish, though, people would look at things as I do. Would I let foreigners see our shipping, would I? No, that I would not: I'd see 'em blind first, but now we are for shewing every thing, and seeing every thing, and saying every thing, and eating and drinking every thing; and giving grand dinners
and suppers, and all manner of luxury, while trade is starving; but they don't care, not they—no—no. 'Tis a shame, I do insist upon it, 'tis a shame to glut∣tonize now; can we call ourselves Englishmen, and indulge ourselves in expensive treats now? in costly meals now? and in dainty dishes now? Ha! tell me that, that's all; only tell me that.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: Mr. Sneer, sir, Mr. Town Clerk has sent you word, that there are no more than three turtles to be had, sir, and two haunches of Venison, and he has bought them all for you.

SP.SPEAKER: SNEER.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I encourage our own islands; turtle is a West-India trade, and as to venison, venison, venison you know, Sir Flimsey, was our forefathers food. I am for the primitive eating of our ances∣tors, no French kickshaws for me. I am for the good old English dish, sir. [Exit, forcing a laugh.] No, no, no French dishes for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: There, there's a rare rascal for ye. Rails against rich feeding, and lives upon turtle and venison.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLIRT, within.
SP.P: Sir Flimsey! Sir Flimsey!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: O, now Landlord, you shall see the mildest, and most affable girl in the universe.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Miss FLIRT.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLIRT.
SP.P: Lord, my dear Sir Flimsey, how can you sit drinking so, to kill yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: There's affection for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLIRT.
SP.P: I insist upon it, you shall not have any more. I know now you are whisp'ring him to bring up t'other bottle, but I'll break it the moment it comes in; upon my soul I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: Well then, my dear, I'll only drink this bumper.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLIRT.
SP.P: But I say you shan't, though: and I think that you must be a sad sort of a man, to encourage any gentleman to kill himself.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: Indeed, madam, I am sure that I don't press my liquor. I am sure, madam, if you was yourself to—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FLIRT.
SP.P: If I was myself—ha—what do you mean? ha, you pityful fellow! Do you think I have been drinking, you vagabond? do you? take that then. [She spits in the Landlord's face, and pulls off his wig, and beats him with it.] I insist upon it, Sir Flimsey, that you come up stairs this minute, and leave that fellow. I insist on it; so come away im∣mediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir FLIMSEY.
SP.P: The sweetest temper'd girl in the universe.

STAGE.HI: Exeunt Sir Flimsey, and Miss Flirt.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: So she is indeed; she is as sweet temper'd as a wolf, and as mild as a mad woman!

SP.SPEAKER: First SAILOR.
SP.P: Sarvant, sarvant, landlord.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: Very welcome, gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: First SAILOR.
SP.P: Come, bear a hand. We han't time to fetch up any lee-way now. Let us be as close haul'd as we can. Keep a good look out, lads, close along shore, for his Majesty king George is coming—so bear a hand with the bowl.

SP.SPEAKER: Second SAILOR.
SP.P: Avast, mess-mates, don't let us go while we stay, let us lye too a little, and take an observation.

SP.SPEAKER: First SAILOR.
SP.P: Never mind longitude nor latitude neither now here's sea room enough, [pointing to the bowl] Come, bring your drinking tacks a-board, my boys,—as to the reckoning, let the Landlord keep it. We'll neither mind line nor log-book now.

DIV2.STAGE:
SONG.
I.
Now safe moor'd, with bowl before us
Messmates heave a hand with me;
Lend a brother sailor chorus,
While he sings our lives at sea.
II.
O'er the wide wave-swelling Ocean,
Toss'd aloft, or tumbled low,
As to fear, 'tis all a notion,
When our time's come, we must go.

SP.SPEAKER: Third SAILOR.
SP.P: Go? ay to be sure: So what signifies being molancholy about the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: First SAILOR.
SP.P: That's right, Jack, we'll stand upon this tack, as long as we can, however, and then as the song says,
SP.STAGE:
SONG.
If we must die, why die we must,
'Tis a birth in which all must belay, mun,
When our debt's due, for Death won't trust,
All hands be ready to pay, mun.
As to life's striking its flag, never fear,
Our cruize is out, that's all, my brother;
In this world we've luff'd it up, thus, and no near,
Then about ship, my boys, for another.

SP.SPEAKER: Second SAILOR.
SP.P: I only wish we had had some of your fair weather sparks, in all their gingerbread rigging, on board of us in the Bay, last cruize, Jack.

SP.SPEAKER: First SAILOR.
SP.P: What would you do with them?

SP.SPEAKER: Third SAILOR.
SP.P: Do with them: why, nothing as I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: First SAILOR.
SP.P: Why then let them keep on shore, — for your beaus on board a-ship are like rats, very trouble∣some vermin, — no more fit for sea service, than brown paper is to make a mainsail.

SP.SPEAKER: Third SAILOR.
SP.P: Come, where stands the glass?

SP.SPEAKER: Second SAILOR.
SP.P: Come, bustle, bustle, Tom.

SP.SPEAKER: First SAILOR.
SP.STAGE:
SONG.
I.
Hark the Boatswain hoarsely bawling,
By top sail sheets and haul-yards stand, boys;
Down top-gallants, down be hauling,
Down your stay-sails, hand boys, hand boys.
Now set the braces,
Don't make wry faces,
But the Lee top-sail sheets let go;
Starboard here,
Larboard there,
Turn your quid,
Take a swear,
Yo, Yo, Yo.
II.
As the tide flows, so time passes,
Life's too short to lose a day, boys;
Load your guns, lads, charge your glasses,
Point your bumpers, fire away, boys:
A full broadside pour,
To those girls on shore,
Who let sailors take them in tow.
Starboard here,
Larboard there,
Turn your quid,
Take a swear,
Yo, Yo, Yo.
III.
Thof the tempest swells the billows
Clear the decks, come drink about, boys;
Punch bowls here we'll make our pillows,
Never heed the wind without, boys.
Tho' the ship may roll,
Heave the lead, sound the bowl,
Mark above water, thus we go.
Starboard here,
Larboard there,
Turn your quid,
Take a swear,
Yo, Yo, Yo.

STAGE.HI: Enter a Sailor, with his arm in a sling.

DIV2.P: What cheer, Jack? What, have you got your arm clued up in the brails?

SP.SPEAKER: JACK. Second Sailor.
SP.P: No; but it is not block and block with my shoulder as it us'd to be, — for going to see father, he ax'd me to take a voyage a hunting with him, —so, when the swabber rigg'd the horses, they brought me one to stow myself on board, that they told me was in such right and tight trim, that she would go upon any tack as fast as a Folkstone cutter.

SP.SPEAKER: First SAILOR.
SP.P: So!

SP.SPEAKER: JACK.
SP.P: So I got up aloft, and clapt myself atwhart ship this'n, and made as much way as the best on um; and to the windward of a gravel-pit we spy'd a hare at anchor, so she weigh'd and bore away, and just as I had overhauled her, my horse came bump ashore upon a stone; the back-stay broke, he pitch'd me over the forecastle, came keel upwards, and unshipped my shoulder; and damme if ever I set sail again for another day's hunting.

SP.SPEAKER: Third SAILOR.
SP.P: Tom Bowling.

SP.SPEAKER: First SAILOR.
SP.P: Ay, ay.

SP.SPEAKER: Third SAILOR.
SP.P: Do heave off that song our Midshipman, Will Jenkins, made about Music, and Quebec, and all those things.

SP.SPEAKER: First SAILOR.
SP.P: Well, well; I will, I will.

DIV2.STAGE:
SONG.
I.
Do you see, as a Sailor, I'll heave off
A bit of a Song in my way;
But if you don't like it, I'll leave off,
I soon can my bawling belay.
Odd lingo's Musicianers write in,
Concerning flats, sharps, and all that;
We Seamen are sharp in our fighting,—
And as to the Frenchmen, they're flat.
II.
Outlandish folks tickle your ears
With Solos, and such sort of stuff;
We Tars have no more than three Cheers,
Which French folks think music enough.
Our Instruments always do wonders,
From round-tops we give serenades,
Our Organs are twenty-four pounders,
Our Concerts are brisk cannonades.
III.
At Haver we play'd well our parts,
Tho' our game they pretended to scoff;
For trumps we turn'd up English hearts,
They threw down their Cards, and sheer'd off.
They have met with their match, now they feel,
Their shuffling and cutting we check,
They were lurch'd at Crown-point, and lost deal,
And faith, they got slamm'd at Quebec.
IV.
For cooks, thof the French folks are neater,
Our messes they never can beat,
Our dishes have so much salt petre,
And as to our balls, they're forc'd meat.
God bless our King George, with three cheers, Sir,
And God bless his Consort, Amen.
In past times we've drubb'd the Mounsieurs, Sir,
For pastime we'll drub them again.

STAGE.HI: A noise is heard behind, and out bolts the Land∣lady in a dishabille, the Methodist disordered, and the Landlord pursuing, the Sailors stop them.

SP.SPEAKER: First SAILOR.
SP.P: Avast, avast, Landlord, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: The matter: why, that woman whom I have always indulged, have I just now caught with that hypocritical rascal. You dog, you have debauched my wife, and pretended to so much religion too.

SP.SPEAKER: First SAILOR.
SP.P: Ay, ay, too much of one thing is always good for nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: Get out of my house, you ungrateful woman; and for you, you hypocritical villain—

SP.SPEAKER: First SAILOR.
SP.P: We'll take charge of him.

SP.SPEAKER: GROANLY.
SP.P: I hope you won't murder me.

SP.SPEAKER: First SAILOR.
SP.P: No, no, only we take you to be rather foul at your heart, so we think a little sea-water will scour you.

STAGE.HI: All the Sailors go off with the Methodist, except the first.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: And now for you, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: Yes, I suppose I am to be sent on board a ship now, and sold for a slave; you want to kidnap me, but I demand justice, for you're a wicked man, so you are, to say such things of me, and spoil my character,—yes, that you would—you want to ruin my reputation,—and what is a woman when her re∣putation's gone?—She's no better than a broken punch bowl; and I will defend my reputation, and my honour, for I am as innocent as the apple of my eye, so I am.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: Innocent!

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLADY.
SP.P: Yes, innocent, and all the world shall know it. I won't have my good name taken away for nothing —no, that I won't, you poor suspicious mean-spirited fellow: but keep your house yourself, do, —see what you will do this hurrying time without me; do, do, do. I never will come into the house again until you have ask'd me pardon, that I won't.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: I don't know whether I am awake, or asleep; in the wrong, or the right; or here, or there, or any where, or no where. Mercy upon us. But she has taken my senses away.

SP.SPEAKER: First SAILOR.
SP.P:
Why then lie too a little, Landlord, and let them come on board you again. What signifies your making a noration about the matter! You see she has got the weather-gage of you, and poured in
such a broadside upon you, that you seem all a-back. —I'll tell you —

STAGE.HI: The Boatswain's Call is heard behind the scenes on one side. The Sailor runs off, calling out, Ay, ay. — The bell rings on the other side, at the same time; the Landlord runs off, crying, Coming, coming.—A loud ballooing behind. Guns fired at a distance.
Then the transparent Scene discovered, which repre∣sents the Ships and Boats, as at the Review.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter SAILORS.

STAGE.HI: A triple Horupipe; — and the Piece concludes with the following

DIV2.STAGE:
SONG.
My Mess-mates aloft, and my Masters below,
Since pleas'd you accept of our Pantomime show,
Our hopes are safe harbour'd, unshipp'd are our fears,
And joyous we gratefully give you three cheers.
II.
Your musical folks may perhaps shew their parts
By this song or that song, but we shew our hearts:
The song all songs, fit for Englishmen's ears,
Is, Britons strike home, boys, with three jolly cheers.
III.
This Stage is our Vessel, we Actors the Crew,
Who luff, or go large, or make Trips to please you;
If, Sirs, no offence in our last Trip appears,
As we take our Departure, accept of — three Cheers.
